awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Future of Work in Health Analytics and Automation: Investigating the Communication that Builds Human-Technology Partnerships
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in technologies such as the internet of things, robotics, and artificial intelligence are transforming work through data-intensive automation, which may eliminate jobs without creating new ones or deskill and diminish existing work. This project will investigate how work is automated to encourage forms that benefit work and workers. The project will expand knowledge about the everyday conversations that shape the implementation of automation, and how leaders make choices about how to have those conversations in the first place. The project will focus on health and healthcare work, with is a context likely to be affected by datafication and automation and likely to provide STEM-related careers for individuals who have the right skills. In healthcare, automation may help providers prevent medical errors, lower the costs of caregiving, and augment or create new forms of work, but the success of such systems depends on how they are designed and implemented. By focusing on the actual communication involved in automation, the project will generate theoretical insights and practical recommendations for leaders in health and analytics organizations, regarding (a) what makes the communication involved in data-intensive automation effective or not, and (b) how to structure and facilitate that communication. The research will be used to create short films and a learning module for students making key career decisions. The films and module will be designed to reach groups underrepresented in STEM and to provide information about STEM careers affected by automation and STEM-related, communication competencies. The project will help students at community colleges and universities understand and prepare for the opportunities and challenges of automation.

Recent research has demonstrated that automation is determined not merely by the features of new technology or pressures to make work more efficient, but by a complex, communicatively-negotiated mix of workers' and managers' ideas about factors such as market forces, professional standards, regulation, industry knowledge, and human and technology workflows. Automation involves intertwined changes in the technologies and organization of work. These changes unfold in and through everyday communication about how work is and ought to be accomplished. Using a combination of interview and observational methods, the project will investigate two theoretically and practically important contexts: (1) Healthcare organizations that develop and implement technologies such as automated metrics dashboards and clinical decisions support systems, and (2) Quantified Self communities where practitioners of personal analytics are creating new human-technology partnerships, new forms of work and play, through automation. Insights from this project will advance research on automation, data-intensive work, communication design, and organizational and technological change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding human-technology partnerships is among the most pressing societal challenges facing humankind today. The public sphere is awash with hype, hope, and fear about how intelligent machines like artificial-intelligence-(AI)-empowered bots and machine learning algorithms will transform how we work, learn, play, and live. This project, CAREER: The Future of Work in Health Analytics and Automation: Investigating the Communication that Builds Human-Technology Partnerships, sought to understand the conversations in which the future of these partnerships will unfold.

Intellectual Merit

This project generated insights about the communication practices involved in automating work. To generate these insights, our research team conducted one-hundred and twenty-two interviews in over sixteen different organizations with workers, technologists, managers, and executives focused on automating health and healthcare work. The team also conducted nearly five hundred hours of observations.

First, we found that efforts to automate work can exacerbate rather than solve the problems targeted by automation. In a study of practitioners’ efforts to streamline their work through automation, we found instead that it contributed to their experience of time as noisy, repetitive, and compressed. Rather than addressing the problems of constant connectivity that so many workers know, automation made it worse. Empowering members to decline tasks rather than automating them proved more effective.

Second, we found that practitioners’ discussions about automation focused on potential problems such as making errors and failing to catch them, codifying human biases rather than addressing them, and breaking trust with workers uncertain about the changing nature of work. Their solutions tended to focus on who they included in conversations. However, in a study of the development of a healthcare automation technology, we found that including the necessary diverse perspectives could also make conflict more difficult and invite hostile communication practices that undermined teams’ interaction. We documented less effective communication strategies that joined in the hostility and more effective communication strategies that confronted the hostility through questions and humor. 

Third, we developed a theory of the communication design of conversations about automation. Thinking about and studying communication is important because it is the substance of automation, because automation involves communication practices, and because our deliberations about automation will influence the human-technology partnerships of the future. Alongside this model, we identified specific communication practices and commitments that facilitated more effective communication about and for automation. These insights are particularly important for the study of automation today because of the centrality and too often taken-for-granted role that data and analytics play in it. In another study, we found that the organizational development and use of metrics makes navigating human-technology partnerships more difficult because data are not just data.  

Broader Impacts

Guided by these insights, we conducted findings workshops with the organizations under study, so they could identify their own action items and put the research findings into practice directly. To date, we have published these insights in five peer reviewed journal articles and three book chapters, and we presented insights from the research in eighteen peer reviewed conference papers. The research effort pulled together a team of faculty and graduate students who founded the Automation Policy Research and Organizing Network or APRON Lab. The research effort mentored dozens of graduate and undergraduate student researchers through the Lab. The project included the development of a graduate-level theory and methods course focused on the techniques deployed in this research and an undergraduate course focused on the future of work for health professions that included content developed through the research. Students’ participation in the lab inspired and guided an undergraduate honors thesis, two MA theses, two PhD dissertations, and multiple career profiles made by and for students. 

The APRON Lab also worked with collaborators at Austin Community College, the Expanding Pathways in Computing program at the Texas Advanced Computing Center, the University of Texas at Austin’s Center for Health Communication and Health Informatics and Health Information Technology program to create and distribute short films to help young people navigate the future of work. Teams of graduate student filmmakers produced, shot, and edited six short films that profiled health care professionals working in health analytics and automation. These films and the Automation of Work / Work of Automation learning module developed by the project provide resources for adoption in classrooms that give folks just starting out a vivid and visceral sense of what it means to work in this space (https://www.apronlab.org/the-future-of-work). In doing so, the project helped broaden the participation of underrepresented groups by creating learning materials targeted to them. And in more general terms, by focusing on automation, the project addressed pressing questions for marginalized communities that will likely be most affected by the disruptions that accompany the future of work. Project data, the Automation of Work / Work of Automation learning module, and the career profile videos were deposited at the Texas Data Respository (https://dataverse.tdl.org/dataverse/apron1750731).
